708317f-a.text:
Thon. Fortune Ryan Residence, N.W. corner Fifth Avenue and 9th Street.

1912.

708319f-a.text:
23-29 Fifth Ave., at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of East 9th Street. Also shown is Nos. 4-6 East 9th Street, south side, east of Fifth Ave.

About 1915.

Brown Brothers.

708321f-a.text:
23 to 27 Fifth Ave., at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of East 9th Street, showing 3 former private residences that have been replaced by a 13-story apartment, No. 25.  The corner structure shown, No. 23, was for many years occupied by Major General Daniel E. Sickles of Gettysburg fame.

About 1915.

Gift of E.M. Jerks.

708320f-a.text:
23 to 27 Fifth Avenue, at adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of E. 9th Street.  The corner structure (no. 23) was occupied for many years by Major-General Daniel E. Sickles of Gettysburg fame. As a matter of fact, he died here.  In 1921 these buildings were demolished and a 13 story apartment house erected upon their sites and which is still standing in 1939.  at the right are two structures, No's 3 and 5 E. 9th Street, that still stand today (1939) and are the property of William Snittenham. At the time this photo was taken No 3 was owned by Fredk. W. Whitridge and No. 5 by Harry W. Bankard.

About 1920

Gift of E.M. Jenks.

708318f-a.text:
Brevoort Mansion, Fifth Avenue at N.W. corner of 9th Street.  An elaborate bel costume held here in 1840 marked the transition in the city's social history from simple entertainments to elaborate balls.

Demolished in 1925 for the construction of an apartment house.

April, 1925.

Brown Brothers, Photographer.

708322f-a.text:
24-26 Fifth Ave. (right), at the N.W. corner of West 9th Street (left), showing the Fifth Ave. Hotel.  It is the successor of the old Fifth Ave. Hotel which was located at the N.W. corner of 23rd Street and Fifth Ave., and was one of New York's leading hostelries.  About 1927.

Abrams Photo Service.

708325f.text: North on Fifth Avenue from 9th street, showing church of the ascension (Protestant-Episcopal) and First Presbyterian Church. 1930.

708314f-b.text:
(1)
19, 21 Fifth Avenue, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of the 9th Street.
February 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr

(2)
21, 19 Fifth Avenue, at ans adjoining the S. E. corner of the 9th Street. No. 21, the corner house, was the home of Mark Twain [Samuel L. Clemens] from 1904 to the middle of 1908. In 1925 the Greenwich Village Association placed a tablet on the north wall commemorating both Mark Twain and Washington Irving, who was at one time a guest in this house.
February 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr

708314f-a.text:
(1)
19, 21 Fifth Avenue, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of the 9th Street.

(2)
21, 19 Fifth Avenue, at ans adjoining the S. E. corner of the 9th Street. No. 21, the corner house, was the home of Mark Twain [Samuel L. Clemens] from 1904 to the middle of 1908. In 1925 the Greenwich Village Association placed a tablet on the north wall commemorating both Mark Twain and Washington Irving, who was at one time a guest in this house.
February 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr

708315f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from 9th Street.
April 26, 1933.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

708316f-a.text:
The Berkeley, 20 Fifth Avenue at the S. W. Corner of 9th Street.
April 16, 1933.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

The New York Sun of December 19, 1936 reports the proposed demolition of this structure and gives the C. B. Ross Company as owner. At the extreme left is the Bret Narte house.
Neg # 525

720150f-b.text:
Greenwich Avenue, northwest from West 9th, 1Oth, and Charles Street's respectively, showing a progressive view of the W. P. A. track removal project on this thoroughfare. In the distant background is the vague outline of the massive New York Port Authority Building
at 111 Eighth Avenue.
June 23, 1937
No's 1-2-3
W. P. A. photo
FIVE BOROUCHS PROIECT

708312f-b.text:
(1) to (3)
Fifth Avenue southeast corner Ninth Street, showing
demolition.  The Berkeley House is being razed.
The view is west on Ninth Street.

P.L. Speer  October 11, 1939.  view 2: Neg. #524

708313f-a.text:
21 and 19 Fifth Ave. (right) at, and adjoining the S.E. corner of East 9th Street. Also shown (left) are Nos. 2, and 4 East 9th Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Fifth Ave. The corner building is the Mark Twain House (21 Fifth Ave. and 2 East 9th Street) in which resided the great American novelist and satirist.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
